metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: The Euclidean Algorithm
Named after the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid, the Euclidean algorithm is the oldest known non-trivial algorithm, described in Euclid's famous book "Elements" from 300 BCE.
content.html: Named after the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid, the Euclidean algorithm is the oldest known non-trivial algorithm, described in Euclid's famous book "Elements" from 300 BCE.

content.text: The Euclidean Algorithm
The Euclidean algorithm finds the greatest common divisor (gcd) of two numbers a a and b b .
content.html: The Euclidean algorithm finds the greatest common divisor (gcd) of two numbers aa and bb.

content.text: The greatest common divisor is the largest number that divides both a a and b b without leaving a remainder.
content.html: The greatest common divisor is the largest number that divides both aa and bb without leaving a remainder.

content.text: Finding the greatest common divisor using division.
content.html: Finding the greatest common divisor using division.

content.text: Result:
content.html: Result:

content.text: The algorithm uses division with remainder. It takes the remainder from the previous step to set up the calculation in the next step.
content.html: The algorithm uses division with remainder. It takes the remainder from the previous step to set up the calculation in the next step.

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: Continue reading to see how the Euclidean algorithm can be done by hand, with programming, and to understand how and why the algorithm actually works.
content.html: Continue reading to see how the Euclidean algorithm can be done by hand, with programming, and to understand how and why the algorithm actually works.

content.text: Mathematical Terminology
Below are words used to describe the Euclidean Algorithm that you need to know to understand the explanations on this page.
content.html: Below are words used to describe the Euclidean Algorithm that you need to know to understand the explanations on this page.

content.text: Divisor: A number we can use to divide a number by, without leaving a remainder. We say that 3 is a divisor of 6 because 6 / 3 = 2 6 / 3 = 2 , without leaving a remainder (the remainder is 0).
content.html: Divisor: A number we can use to divide a number by, without leaving a remainder. We say that 3 is a divisor of 6 because 6/3=26/3=2, without leaving a remainder (the remainder is 0).

content.text: Remainder: The part you are left with after dividing a number with another number. Dividing 7 by 3 is 2, with a remainder of 1. (So 3 is not a divisor of 7.)
content.html: Remainder: The part you are left with after dividing a number with another number. Dividing 7 by 3 is 2, with a remainder of 1. (So 3 is not a divisor of 7.)

content.text: Common divisor: For numbers a a and b b , a common divisor is a number that can divide both a a and b b without leaving a remainder. The common divisors of 18 and 12 are 2, 3, and 6, because both 18 and 12 can be divided by 2, 3, and 6 without producing a remainder.
content.html: Common divisor: For numbers aa and bb, a common divisor is a number that can divide both aa and bb without leaving a remainder. The common divisors of 18 and 12 are 2, 3, and 6, because both 18 and 12 can be divided by 2, 3, and 6 without producing a remainder.

content.text: Greatest common divisor: The largest of the common divisors. The greatest common divisor of 18 and 12 is 6 because that is the largest of the common divisors 2, 3, and 6.
content.html: Greatest common divisor: The largest of the common divisors. The greatest common divisor of 18 and 12 is 6 because that is the largest of the common divisors 2, 3, and 6.

content.text: The greatest common divisor is used in the mathematical field of Number Theory, and in cryptography for encrypting messages.
content.html: The greatest common divisor is used in the mathematical field of Number Theory, and in cryptography for encrypting messages.

content.text: Note: All numbers used by the Euclidean algorithm are integers.
content.html: Note: All numbers used by the Euclidean algorithm are integers.

content.text: Manual Run Through
To understand how the Euclidean algorithm works, and to write the code for it, let's first run it manually to find the greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 .
content.html: To understand how the Euclidean algorithm works, and to write the code for it, let's first run it manually to find the greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525.

content.text: To do this we use division with remainder.
content.html: To do this we use division with remainder.

content.text: Step 1: We start with dividing 120 120 with 25 25 :
content.html: Step 1: We start with dividing 120120 with 2525:
120=4⋅25+20120=4⋅25+20

content.text: How many times can we fit 25 25 inside 120 120 ? It is 4 4 times, right? 4 ⋅ 25 4 ⋅ 25 is 100 100 . We get the remainder 20 20 by subtracting 100 100 from 120 120 .
content.html: How many times can we fit 2525 inside 120120? It is 44 times, right? 4⋅254⋅25 is 100100. We get the remainder 2020 by subtracting 100100 from 120120.

content.text: Step 2: We use the previous remainder 20 20 in the next step to divide 25 25 :
content.html: Step 2: We use the previous remainder 2020 in the next step to divide 2525:
25=1⋅20+525=1⋅20+5

content.text: We can fit 20 20 inside 25 25 one time. We get the remainder 5 5 by subtracting 20 20 from 25 25 .
content.html: We can fit 2020 inside 2525 one time. We get the remainder 55 by subtracting 2020 from 2525.

content.text: Step 3: In the next calculation we divide 20 20 with the previous remainder 5 5 :
content.html: Step 3: In the next calculation we divide 2020 with the previous remainder 55:
20=4⋅5+020=4⋅5+0

content.text: We get 0 0 as the remainder, and that means that we are done with the calculations.
content.html: We get 00 as the remainder, and that means that we are done with the calculations.

content.text: The greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 is 5 5 .
content.html: The greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525 is 55.

content.text: Implementation of The Euclidean Algorithm
To find the greatest common divisor using division, we continue running the algorithm until the remainder calculated is 0 0 .
content.html: To find the greatest common divisor using division, we continue running the algorithm until the remainder calculated is 00.

content.text: This is the same as saying we continue to run the algorithm as long as b b is not 0 0 . That is why b != 0 is the condition in the while loop below.
content.html: This is the same as saying we continue to run the algorithm as long as bb is not 00. That is why b != 0 is the condition in the while loop below.

content.code_html:
def gcd_division(a, b):
    while b != 0:
        remainder = a % b
        print(f"{a} = {a//b} * {b} + {remainder}")
        a = b
        b = remainder
    return a

a = 120
b = 25
print("The Euclidean algorithm using division:\n")
print(f"The GCD of {a} and {b} is: {gcd_division(a, b)}")

content.text: The Original Euclidean Algorithm
Instead of using division like we did above, the original Euclidean algorithm as described in the book "Elements" over 2000 years ago uses subtraction.
content.html: Instead of using division like we did above, the original Euclidean algorithm as described in the book "Elements" over 2000 years ago uses subtraction.

content.text: Finding the greatest common divisor using subtraction.
content.html: Finding the greatest common divisor using subtraction.

content.text: Result:
content.html: Result:

content.text: How the Euclidean algorithm with subtraction works:
content.html: How the Euclidean algorithm with subtraction works:

content.text: Using subtraction instead of division is not as fast, but both the division method and the subtraction method uses the same mathematical principle:
content.html: Using subtraction instead of division is not as fast, but both the division method and the subtraction method uses the same mathematical principle:

content.text: The greatest common divisor of numbers a a and b b , is also the greatest common divisor of the difference between a a and b b .
content.html: The greatest common divisor of numbers aa and bb, is also the greatest common divisor of the difference between aa and bb.

content.text: This can be shown in just a few lines.
content.html: This can be shown in just a few lines.

content.text: Numbers a a and b b have a greatest common divisor x x .
content.html: Numbers aa and bb have a greatest common divisor xx.

content.text: This means that both a a and b b can be factorized like this:
content.html: This means that both aa and bb can be factorized like this:

content.text: a = k ⋅ x b = l ⋅ x a = k ⋅ x b = l ⋅ x
content.html: a=k⋅xb=l⋅xa=k⋅xb=l⋅x

content.text: After factorization, subtracting b b from a a gives us a very interesting result:
content.html: After factorization, subtracting bb from aa gives us a very interesting result:

content.text: a − b = k ⋅ x − l ⋅ x = ( k − l ) ⋅ x a − b = k ⋅ x − l ⋅ x = ( k − l ) ⋅ x
content.html: a−b=k⋅x−l⋅x=(k−l)⋅xa−b=k⋅x−l⋅x=(k−l)⋅x

content.text: We can see that the greatest common divisor ( x x ) of a a and b b is also the greatest common divisor of the difference between a a and b b !
content.html: We can see that the greatest common divisor (xx) of aa and bb is also the greatest common divisor of the difference between aa and bb!

content.text: This principle is why the Euclidean algorithm works, it is what makes it possible.
content.html: This principle is why the Euclidean algorithm works, it is what makes it possible.

content.text: Finding The Greatest Common Divisor Using Subtraction

Using the principle described above, that the difference between a a and b b also shares the same greatest common divisor, we can use subtraction to find the greatest common divisor, like Euclid's original algorithm does.
content.html: Using the principle described above, that the difference between aa and bb also shares the same greatest common divisor, we can use subtraction to find the greatest common divisor, like Euclid's original algorithm does.

content.text: Let's find the greatest common divisor of 120 120 from 25 25 using subtraction.
content.html: Let's find the greatest common divisor of 120120 from 2525 using subtraction.
120−25=95120−25=95

content.text: According to the mathematical principle already described, the numbers 120 120 , 25 25 , and 95 95 all share the same greatest common divisor.
content.html: According to the mathematical principle already described, the numbers 120120, 2525, and 9595 all share the same greatest common divisor.

content.text: This means we can further reduce our problem by subtracting 25 25 from 95 95 :
content.html: This means we can further reduce our problem by subtracting 2525 from 9595:
95−25=7095−25=70

content.text: If we continue like this, always taking the two lowest numbers from the previous step and finding the difference between them, we get these calculations:
content.html: If we continue like this, always taking the two lowest numbers from the previous step and finding the difference between them, we get these calculations:
70−25=4545−25=2025−20=520−5=1515−5=1010−5=5––5−5=070−25=4545−25=2025−20=520−5=1515−5=1010−5=5_5−5=0

content.text: The Euclidean algorithm using subtraction is done when the difference is 0 0 .
content.html: The Euclidean algorithm using subtraction is done when the difference is 00.

content.text: The greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 can be found in the previous step, it is 5 5 .
content.html: The greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525 can be found in the previous step, it is 55.

content.text: Now that we can calculate the greatest common divisor using subtraction by hand, it is easier to implement it in a programming language.
content.html: Now that we can calculate the greatest common divisor using subtraction by hand, it is easier to implement it in a programming language.

content.text: Implementation of The Euclidean Algorithm Using Subtraction
To find the greatest common divisor using subtraction, we continue running the algorithm until the difference between a a and b b is 0 0 , like we have just seen.
content.html: To find the greatest common divisor using subtraction, we continue running the algorithm until the difference between aa and bb is 00, like we have just seen.

content.text: This is the same as saying we continue running the algorithm as long as a a and b b are different values. That is why a != b is the condition in the while loop below.
content.html: This is the same as saying we continue running the algorithm as long as aa and bb are different values. That is why a != b is the condition in the while loop below.

content.code_html:
def gcd_subtraction(a, b):
    while a != b:
        if a > b:
            print(f"{a} - {b} = {a-b}")
            a = a - b
        else:
            print(f"{b} - {a} = {b-a}")
            b = b - a
    return a

a = 120
b = 25
print("The Euclidean algorithm using subtraction:\n")
print(f"The GCD of {a} and {b} is: {gcd_subtraction(a, b)}")

content.text: Comparing The Subtraction Method With The Division Method
To see how good the division method can be to find the greatest common divisor, and how the methods are similar, we will:
content.html: To see how good the division method can be to find the greatest common divisor, and how the methods are similar, we will:

content.text: 1. Using Subtraction
Finding the greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 using subtraction:
content.html: Finding the greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525 using subtraction:
120−25=9595−25=7070−25=4545−25=2025−20=520−5=1515−5=1010−5=5––5−5=0120−25=9595−25=7070−25=4545−25=2025−20=520−5=1515−5=1010−5=5_5−5=0

content.text: Using subtraction, the algorithm is finished when the difference is 0 0 .
content.html: Using subtraction, the algorithm is finished when the difference is 00.

content.text: In the second last calculation we see that the greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 is 5 5 .
content.html: In the second last calculation we see that the greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525 is 55.

content.text: Notice how 25 25 and 5 5 must be subtracted many times, until finding the GCD.
content.html: Notice how 2525 and 55 must be subtracted many times, until finding the GCD.

content.text: 2. Using Division
Finding the greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 using division with remainder looks like this:
content.html: Finding the greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525 using division with remainder looks like this:
120=4⋅25+2025=1⋅20+5––20=4⋅5+0120=4⋅25+2025=1⋅20+5_20=4⋅5+0

content.text: Using division, the Euclidean algorithm is finished when the remainder is 0 0 .
content.html: Using division, the Euclidean algorithm is finished when the remainder is 00.

content.text: The previous remainder 5 5 is the greatest common divisor of 120 120 and 25 25 .
content.html: The previous remainder 55 is the greatest common divisor of 120120 and 2525.

content.text: 3. Comparison
Take a look at the subtraction and division methods above.
content.html: Take a look at the subtraction and division methods above.

content.text: To easier see that the division calculations are basically the same as the subtraction calculations, we can write the division with remainder calculations like this:
content.html: To easier see that the division calculations are basically the same as the subtraction calculations, we can write the division with remainder calculations like this:
120−4⋅25=2025−1⋅20=5––20−4⋅5=0120−4⋅25=2025−1⋅20=5_20−4⋅5=0

content.text: Using subtraction, 25 25 is subtracted from 120 120 a total of 4 4 times, while the division method does this in just one step.
content.html: Using subtraction, 2525 is subtracted from 120120 a total of 44 times, while the division method does this in just one step.

content.text: Similarly, the subtraction method subtracts 5 5 a total of 4 4 times, while the division method does the same in just one calculation.
content.html: Similarly, the subtraction method subtracts 55 a total of 44 times, while the division method does the same in just one calculation.

content.text: As you can see, the methods do the same thing, the division method just does many subtractions in the same calculation, so that it finds the greatest common divisor faster.
content.html: As you can see, the methods do the same thing, the division method just does many subtractions in the same calculation, so that it finds the greatest common divisor faster.
